Award.AwardTitle: Probing Unusual Kinetic Isotope Effects in Ozone Formation through Crossed Beam and Bulk Photochemistry Experiments
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this award, co-funded by the Experimental Physical Chemistry Program of the Division of Chemistry and the Atmospheric Chemistry Program of the Atmospheric Sciences Division (Geosciences Directorate), Professor Kristie A. Boering of the University of California - Berkeley, together with her graduate student researchers, will investigate the chemistry of oxygen in order to determine the root-cause for the unusual isotopic fractionation observed in atmospheric ozone. The Boering group will carry out bulk photochemical investigations in their laboratory in Berkeley and will travel to Taiwan to carry out a number of crossed-beam investigations of the atomic + molecular oxygen exchange reaction in the laboratories of the Institute of Atomic and Molecular Sciences of Academica Sinica. In addition, these experimental studies will be supplemented with theoretical investigations by Prof. Dmitri Babikov of Marquette University and Prof. Hua Guo of the University of New Mexico, as well as Prof Gy√∂rgy Lendvay of the Hungarian Academy of Sciences.

Isotopic patterns in atmospheric gases can be used to glean clues into the complicated workings of the earth's atmosphere. The ozone isotope anomaly is still mysterious, and is not completely explicable with standard chemical models. The ozone isotope anomaly is transferred to other important trace gases, including carbon dioxide and nitrous oxide. Developing a firm understanding of the trace isotope fractionation in these gases will allow scientists to develop robust models of the atmosphere -- which are important in climate change research. Besides the broad scientific impact of this work, Prof. Boering's students are experiencing the kind of globe-spanning research effort that is becoming more of the norm in modern science -- thus training them to be the kind of globally-engaged scientists that our society will need in the future.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Chemical compounds found in the atmosphere vary in space and time; studying their concentrations allows inferences to be made regarding how these compounds enter and leave the atmosphere. In addition, the isotopic composition of a particular compound can also vary in space and time, providing additional information about its sources and fate in the atmosphere. One such compound is ozone, O3, which can be composed of 3 different stable isotopes: 16O, 17O, and 18O. How 16O, 17O, and 18O are distributed in ozone in the laboratory and atmosphere is not governed by standard chemical physics. For example, standard theory predicts that 17O and 18O should be depleted slightly in ozone formed from the reaction of oxygen atoms with oxygen molecules (O2) relative to the abundances of 17O and 18O in the initial O2. Yet what is observed are extremely large enrichments in 17O and 18O in ozone. This unusual isotope behavior is interesting both from a chemical physics point of view and for applications to atmospheric chemistry on Earth and beyond.

In this project, we studied the chemical physics of isotope effects in ozone formation, isotope effects in collisions between oxygen atoms and nitrogen dioxide (NO2), and how the unusual isotopic composition of ozone is transferred to other atmospheric species, such as carbon dioxide (CO2) and nitrogen dioxide (NO2). First, we analyzed data from an earlier project in which we studied the physics of collisions between a beam of oxygen atoms and a beam of O2. We detected oxygen atom exchange between O and O2 by starting with a beam of 18O atoms and a beam of 16O16O molecules and then detecting 18O16O molecules after the beams crossed in the experimental apparatus. The angular and velocity distribution of the products revealed new information on the chemical physics of the reaction, which proceeds on the same potential energy surface as ozone formation, and new benchmarks for theory. Second, we measured how the isotopic composition of O3 changed in experiments when different "bath" gases were used to stabilize the ozone intermediate. Interestingly, we found that ozone formation in modest pressures of sulfur hexafluoride (SF6) resulted in ozone with an isotopic composition of the initial O2. These results also reveal new information about the chemical physics of the isotope effects in ozone formation in that using a bath gas with many, low energy degrees of freedom completely eliminated the unusual isotope effects in ozone formation. Third, we used laboratory measurements and computer models to successfully show that the unusual isotopic composition of CO2 results solely from the transfer of the 17O and 18O anomalies in O3, resolving some long-standing discrepancies between laboratory results and calculations and between laboratory results and stratospheric observations. Fourth, we studied the chemical physics of collisions between oxygen atoms and NO2 molecules to better understand by what mechanism the reactions proceed, the physics underlying their reaction rate coefficients, and whether isotope effects in these reactions can affect the unusual isotopic composition of nitrates used in environmental studies to determine the origin of nitrates in groundwater. To date, the following manuscripts have been published or are currently under review:
